.@agripulse's coverage of today's hearing to consider the nomination of Janie Simms Hipp features her responses to questions from Ranking Member @JohnBoozman, @SenatorFischer & @RogerMarshallMD https://twitter.com/agripulse/status/1397946766041944072 QT @agripulse USDA general counsel nominee pledges to work with DOJ on livestock pricing https://www.agri-pulse.com/articles/15953-usda-general-counsel-nominee-pledges-to-work-with-doj-on-livestock-pricing

RT @agripulse .@SenateAgGOP ranking member @JohnBoozman  says in opening to Janie Hipp nomination hearing that panel needs to look into livestock marketing issues. Chairwoman @SenStabenow says committee needs to 'work together and find solutions'

RT @agripulse .@USDA general counsel nom Janie Hipp assures @JohnBoozman she will communicate with committee on legal opinions: 'I  believe in frank discussions. Sometimes folks misinterpret the law and you have to explain what the law says'

Ms. Hipp responds by saying ‚Äúhappy to take a look at it if confirmed.‚Äù She notes that agriculture needs legal talent that very specialized & says it will serve us well to encourage more intern programs like that.

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äî ‚ÄúIf confirmed, do you commit to supporting the NALC at @UARKLaw during your tenure? And will you recommit to executing a fresh MOU to allow this collaborative program between the NALC and USDA to continue to flourish?

RM @JohnBoozman says this MOU would facilitate NALC Research Fellows gaining legal experience and guidance by USDA OGC attorneys which would help the fellows gain educational excellence and develop legal talent in agricultural law ‚Äì a win for both NALC and USDA.
RM @JohnBoozman calls NALC ‚Äúa treasure that Congressional Members and their staff rely upon to get updates on legal matters affecting agriculture.‚Äù

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì Asks the nominee about the expired MOU USDA had entered into with the National Agricultural Law Center to provide a cooperative framework for the parties to develop and maintain an unpaid legal internship program.

RM @JohnBoozman asks the nominee to commit to transparency by publishing legal opinions on administration policy proposals, including briefing Congress on those opinions and Ms. Hipp responds by promising to be transparent with Congress and stakeholders.

RM @JohnBoozman mentions concerns for future of USDA‚Äôs new swine inspection system. "Due to a court ruling, USDA will need to reconsider this program & chose a path forward. Their decision will impact thousands of hog farmers, so I implore you to weigh this decision carefully.‚Äù

RM @JohnBoozman notes that USDA has access to resources to help farmers across the country recover from COVID-19 and urges the nominee, if confirmed, to do all she can to assist in breaking the log-jam, releasing the funds & expediting the regulatory review process.

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúI also hope OGC can assist USDA in releasing nearly $2 billion in financial relief to contract poultry & livestock producers & expediting the regulatory approval for billions more in assistance to producers of agricultural commodities affected by the pandemic.‚Äù
RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúTransparency is key to a good working relationship with Congress, and the lack of it shown so far by the department is concerning to say the least.‚Äù
RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúI expect OGC and the department to follow the call to transparency on important issues, by providing Congress and the public with the basis of its positions.‚Äù

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúI remain opposed to any effort to shoehorn the establishment & operation of a carbon bank into the CCC authority & I ask USDA for details & to provide comprehensive legal justification for the establishment of a bank prior to any such action taking place.‚Äù

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúFor instance, I remain concerned the administration may force the establishment of a bank through the CCC that would intervene in markets for environmental offsets, or pay farmers, ranchers, and forest-owners for anything carbon.‚Äù
RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúAggies have many concerns these days, some of which are a direct result of action, or inaction, by the department.‚Äù

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúIt is important USDA has a general counsel who can be relied upon by Congress and the agriculture community to provide sound, practical, and candid legal guidance to the department.
RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúIt is truly great to see a fellow Razorback serving our broad agricultural community with such dedication.‚Äù

RM @JohnBoozman ‚Äì ‚ÄúShe has a deep bond in Arkansas, earning an LL.M. in agriculture and food law from @UARKLaw; and serving in various positions at the National Center for Agricultural Law Research and Information at @UARKLaw.‚Äù

There are many interesting moves being made in the field of CCs. It very much is the Wild West of finance. They make new things possible, which isn‚Äôt always a good thing. They can have consequences no one expected. This field deserves a great deal of attention going forward.

So how does this relate to Colonial Pipeline? Bitcoins only exist as data. They can be tied to digital wallets rather than a specific person‚Äôs identity, which means people believe they can receive and spend them anonymously- perfect for secret transactions like ransoms.

This means that, as bitcoin gets more valuable, more people mine, mining gets harder, it takes more computations and more electricity to mine a bitcoin. Some of you may be familiar with @elonmusk recent statement about bitcoin‚Äôs carbon footprint.

In short, the more miners there are, the harder it is to mine bitcoins. Since the best way to mine is to simply use more computations, there is an incentive to pool as much effort into mining as possible, simply to make sure your pool has an advantage over other miners.

The interesting thing is that you can make it easier or harder to form new blocks if you make the nonce higher or lower. And for bitcoin, the difficulty is adjusted every 2016 blocks so that the rate of formation of new blocks is constant.

Despite the randomness, it's more like they‚Äôre getting paid a fee to maintain ledgers than mining or creating bitcoins. Miners provide proof that they‚Äôve done work to contribute to the chain in exchange for compensation (in bitcoins), rather than making bitcoins themselves.

The first person to win a block gets a prize of bitcoins. Since the second step in forming a block is essentially up to chance, the most effective way to mine is simply to throw more computation at the problem, verifying as many blocks as possible as fast as possible.

You may ask ‚Äúwhy not just guess 000‚Ä¶0001 for your hash, if the goal is to get a hash below the target nonce?‚Äù The answer: your guess is put through what is basically a randomizing equation based on several inputs, like the timestamp. Guessing your hash ahead of time is #noncense

In short, mining a new bitcoin is a two-step process. First, you need to verify a block‚Äôs worth of transactions, then you need to guess a hash (a number). Your guess is compared to a target (called a nonce) and if your guess is below the nonce then you form a block.

Since #bitcoins are decentralized, there isn‚Äôt a government or bank to maintain the system, which means there needs to be a different way. People who verify transactions are bitcoin miners, and the process of verification is fundamental to how they make (or mine) new bitcoins.

These protocols revolve around cryptography (for computers, this is the use of math to code information) hence ‚Äúcrypto‚Äùcurrencies. However, someone needs to actually verify each new block in the chain to keep the system running smoothly.

This blockchain of transactions forms a distributed ledger that is difficult to modify and easy to verify (in theory); a ledger that is maintained collectively on a network with specific protocols to verify each new block in the chain, meaning that bitcoin exchanges are secure.

Using bitcoin as an example: bitcoins exist in digital ledgers, but to prevent fraudulent exchanges, transactions are recorded in encrypted blocks. Each block points at the previous block and has a timestamp. Go where each block points and you get a chain, called a ‚Äúblockchain‚Äù.

The software used to make new CCs exists and is publicly available, which means that developing a new CC can be done in as little as a few hours. Honestly, it looks like a return to the days when each bank printed their own notes.

CCs exist only in digital ledgers and wallets rather than as physical objects like dollar bills. Like all fiat currencies, they have value only because people agree they do, but CCs in general lack the backing of a government or central bank.

Some people decided that, if the commodity backing a currency doesn‚Äôt matter, then why should money need to be a physical object and why should you need a government (or bank) to back money? From there, some programmers started developing cryptocurrencies (CCs).

Some history: in the last century governments have moved away from commodity currencies (such as gold) to fiat currencies (such as Federal Reserve notes) cementing the idea that money can have value just because people agree it does.

Software developments, however, mean that they don‚Äôt need to bother with masks and voice modulators. They can issue a ransom and request payment with a cryptocurrency (CC) (like bitcoin) rather than exchange a briefcase full of cash.

Hostage and ransom payments are a practice that has been applied in different contexts for thousands of years, ranging from prisoner exchanges to kidnappings. Today, a person collecting a ransom payment does not want their identity publicly tied to a ransom.

6/ We can‚Äôt fix all of the problems with the NCAA from Washington. What we can do is give the college athletes who are being taken advantage of the power to fix things through their own collective action.

5/ This is a matter of basic fairness, but it‚Äôs also a civil rights issue. The athletes in the most high-profile sports are overwhelmingly Black men and women, while those with the power are largely white.

RT @WhiteHouse Higher wages and more options for workers ‚Äì is a good thing.

No one single policy will close the racial wealth gap alone, but they can form part of a broad basket of policy solutions each contributing to help narrow the divide one hundred years after the destruction of Black lives, wealth, and financial independence in Tulsa. #Tulsa100

Structural solutions are needed to close the racial wealth gap.

Read more here: http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E2ZysyXVgAUXeom.png

While higher educational attainment is generally associated with more accumulated wealth, Black and Hispanic families have less median family wealth than white families with the same education. Education alone can‚Äôt close the racial wealth gap. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E2ZyodbXIAEQnF6.jpg

The white-Black gap in median wealth has remained relatively unchanged for decades, shifting from $134,000 in 1989 to $164,000 in 2019. While the gap narrows marginally after economic contractions, the impact on Black wealth lingers. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E2ZykPfXoAAP8d6.jpg

Black Tulsans have yet to recover. The typical Black household in Tulsa has only six cents of wealth for every one dollar of the typical white household.

This mirrors the country‚Äôs racial wealth gap. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E2ZydDsVcAEuuOs.jpg

White rioters decimated more than $27 million of Black property in today‚Äôs dollars. The 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre resulted in a decline in home ownership, lower average occupational status, net worth, and educational attainment for Blacks in Tulsa.

Much of this wealth was destroyed in the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre, which left hundreds of residents dead. On the fateful day of May 31, 1921, a violent white mob destroyed more than 1,200 homes across 35 city blocks, and more than 300 homes were looted.

In 1921, the Greenwood District in Tulsa, Oklahoma, was home to one of the most affluent African-American communities in America. More than 70 businesses, mostly owned by Black Americans, lined up in just the 100 block of Greenwood Ave. in Tulsa, also known as Black Wall Street.

Let me be clear: I won't allow this bill to be watered down or minimized. I won't allow the voices of survivors to be silenced. And I will not stop fighting until the Military Justice Improvement and Increasing Prevention Act is given the full floor vote that it deserves.

It's time to pass this bill ‚Äî and we have the votes to do it. Every day this week, I've stood and asked for #MJIIPA to receive a full vote on the floor of the Senate.

But every single day, I've been refused.

#MJIIPA removes the decision to prosecute serious crimes out of the chain of command and gives it to trained military prosecutors. It's supported by survivors, service members, commanders, and legal experts. And now we have 65 bipartisan Senate cosponsors.

Over the last few years, the rate of sexual assault in the military has soared to historic highs. But the rate of prosecutions and convictions has plummeted. Our military justice system is failing our service members ‚Äî and they're demanding action.

The Military Justice Improvement and Increasing Prevention Act has 65 bipartisan cosponsors ‚Äî a filibuster-proof majority.

So why hasn't it been passed yet? Here's what's going on:

We have an obligation to our colleagues, our staff, and the brave members of the Capitol Police to investigate exactly what led to the deadly violence of January 6th. This shouldn't be a partisan issue. We can't move forward without accountability or justice.

#MJIIPA has 65 bipartisan cosponsors ‚Äî a filibuster-proof majority. We could pass this bill today and secure justice for survivors of military sexual assault.
